head.title: Why Judge Feminism if We Can't Even Define It?; Women's Large Stake

hedline.hl1: Why Judge Feminism if We Can't Even Define It?; Women's Large Stake

block.p: Re ''In Poll, Americans Reject Means but Not Ends of Racial Diversity'' (front page, Dec. 14): Attacks on affirmative action also imperil efforts to expand opportunities for women. Women's stake in this debate must not be overlooked.

Re ''In Poll, Americans Reject Means but Not Ends of Racial Diversity'' (front page, Dec. 14): Attacks on affirmative action also imperil efforts to expand opportunities for women. Women's stake in this debate must not be overlooked.

The task of opening doors -- whether to entry-level jobs or executive suites -- is far from finished. Whether they graduate from high school, college or law school, women still receive less pay and fewer opportunities for advancement than male colleagues of equal standing.

Too many employers still question whether a woman will be as committed to her job as a man, whether she can be as strong a leader or as competent a technician. Affirmative action is about challenging decision makers who favor connections, stereotypes and familiarity over merit.
JUDITH L. LICHTMAN Pres., Women's Legal Defense Fund Washington, Dec. 16, 1997
